newsitem.title: USA: Sallie Mae holders vote for dissident plan.
newsitem.headline: Sallie Mae holders vote for dissident plan.

text.p: Student Loan Marketing Association shareholders voted Thursday to privatise the government-sponsored enterprise through a plan put forward by a dissident group.
At a special meeting in Washingtin, shareholders also chose a 15-member board of directors nominated by the Committee to Restore Value (CRV), a group opposed to existing management.
William Arceneaux, outgoing chairman due to the vote, said shareholders had voted overwhelmingly to privatise the company and restructure it according to CRV's proposal.
"Preliminary results indicate the shareholders owning 80 percent of the shares (voted to) recharter the company as a wholly private entity," Arceneaux said.
"Preliminary results show a majority of the shares present in voting have selected the slate of nominees representing the CRV to be appointed as the initial board of directors," he added.
The vote ended months of dueling between CRV and Sallie Mae and set into motion the privatisation ordered by Congress.
With newly elected Chief Executive Officer Albert Lord, CRV plans to expand the company's student loan operations by originating loans and competing directly with other lenders.
Edward Fox will become the new chairman.

Shareholders rejected a slate proposed by Sallie Mae management that would have included five CRV members on the 15-person board. The management proposal was designed to appeal to a wider range of shareholders while maintaining the current management direction.
Sallie Mae purchases student loans from banks, keeping some in its portfolio and securitizing others for sale to investors.
Lord and Fox plan to expand Sallie Mae's business to include the origination of student loans.
